prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Remedies for Breach of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: An account of profits is an equitable claim that may be made as an alternative to a claim for damages.[1] While the appropriate remedy in the case of breach of contract is generally in damages, other causes of action may require different remedies. For an action based on breach of confidence, courts do have jurisdiction to grant a remedy based on the facts of the case rather than strict doctrinal consideration. Accordingly, in certain circumstances a party may request an equitable remedy such as an accounting of profits as remedy for breach of confidence.[2] The statement of claim in such an action should include an allegation of breach of both contract and the equitable duty of confidence. The object of ordering an accounting is to deprive the defendant of profits improperly made as a result of wrongful acts committed in breach of the plaintiff's rights, and to transfer such profits to the plaintiff.[3] However, in the case of an account of profits, the defendant's gain at the plaintiff's expense is irrelevant.[4]

In RBC Dominion Securities Inc. v. Merrill Lynch Canada Inc.,[5] McLachlin C.J.C., writing for the majority, held that because the trial judge took into account the use of confidential information in making a global loss of profits award against the defendants, it was inappropriate to award additional damages against the investment advisors for improper use of confidential information. An account of profits is often sought where the defendant has made a more extensive use of the confidential business information than the plaintiff would have,[6] because that deprives the defendant of profits made as a result of the wrongdoing. An accounting will be ordered as of the time the defendant knew or ought to have known of the infringement.[7]

Although the plaintiff must elect between an accounting and a claim for damages, the court retains the discretion to decide which remedy is more appropriate in the circumstances.[8] The election of remedy is required to avoid double recovery. However, it has been argued that:

Where … a defendant has not only made profits but also disrupted a plaintiff's business, it seems wrong that a plaintiff should not get the damages associated with the latter injury as well as the defendant's profits.[9]

An accounting is only available where the defendant committed the breach deliberately or intentionally and where the confidential information was a material factor in the profit earned by the defendant. Where the defendant has not made any profits or has made profits not linked to the breach of confidence, no order for an account of profits will be made.[10]

Usually an account of profits will be based on the difference between the sale price charged by the infringing party for objects made using the plaintiff's technology, and the cost to the infringing party of producing the goods. In Peter Pan Manufacturing Corp. v. Corsets Silhouette Ltd.,[11] the infringing party held that profits should be calculated by assessing the difference between the profits made from selling the goods manufactured using the confidential business information and the profits that would have been made if the goods had been made without using the information.[12] The court held that, in a case where the product could have been manufactured without the confidential business information and the information simply rendered manufacture more efficient or less expensive, the method of calculating the loss suggested by the defendant in Peter Pan might be appropriate.

If the plaintiff believes the defendant's gain is much greater than the plaintiff's loss, it may be wise to sue for an account of profits. An order for an account of profits will normally be wide enough to include all profits made by the defendant from the acts in breach of confidence.

In GasTOPS Ltd. v. Forsyth[13] the principal issue on appeal was the trial judge's use of ten years as the timeframe for the assessment of damages and for the disgorgement of profits. The trial judge found the personal appellants liable to the respondent for breach of fiduciary duty, breach of confidence and breach of their contract of employment. The corporate appellant was found liable for breach of confidence. The trial judge awarded damages against the personal appellants equivalent to the profits earned by the corporate appellant from military contracts in its first ten years of operation, and he ordered the corporate appellant to disgorge those profits. All appellants were ordered to pay this amount jointly and severally quantified at $12,306,495.[14]

The trial judge found that all of the personal appellants, former employees, owed a fiduciary duty to the respondent. He held that they breached this duty in a number of ways, particularly in the way they left their employment and in the ways they continued to act after they did so. More particularly, they breached their fiduciary duty by leaving without giving reasonable notice knowing other employees would follow, with devastating effects on the respondent that left it unable to fulfill its contracts or pursue the business opportunities it planned for; they breached their fiduciary duty by soliciting the customers and prospective customers of their former employer; and they breached their fiduciary duty by using the respondent's confidential information to compete unfairly with their former employer. Second, the trial judge found that all the appellants, including the corporate appellant, acquired information that was confidential to the respondent. Third, the trial judge found the four personal appellants liable for breach of contract for leaving their employment without giving reasonable notice.[15]

As against the four personal appellants, the trial judge ordered damages as the remedy for their breach of fiduciary duty, their breach of the duty of confidence, and their breach of contract. He made a single damage award to redress the respondent's loss from the combined effect of these causes of action. He did not assess the consequences of each separately. The Court of Appeal observed that to do so would have been both impractical and unrealistic, given the closely intertwined facts that informed each breach.[16]

The appellants challenged the “accounting period” used by the trial judge to calculate the number of years of improper profits to be disgorged. The trial judge found that ten years was the time over which the corporate appellant earned profits in breach of its duty of confidence which it must disgorge, and ten years was the duration of the losses suffered by the respondent due to the breach of fiduciary duty by the four personal appellants, for which they had to pay damages. This reflected the highly specialized nature of the respondent's business, the time required to develop and evolve its suite of products, and the useful life of the confidential information taken from it.[17]

In dismissing the appeal, the court stated that two reasons pointed to the need for appellate deference. First, the ten-year accounting period was an integral component of the remedy ordered by the trial judge for breach of confidence and breach of fiduciary duty. Both these causes of action require the exercise of equitable principles as does the remedy for each. Second, it was clear from the trial judge's reasons that the selection of ten years for the accounting period was a very fact-driven exercise. That too suggested appellate deference.[18]

The Court of Appeal rejected the appellants argument that the ten-year accounting period was well in excess of the temporal limits set by the case law, whether for breach of fiduciary duty, or for breach of confidence, or for failure to give notice. The trial judge did not assess the accounting period required for each cause of action separately. He decided upon the accounting period as an integral part of the remedy for the harm caused by the combined effect of all these breaches. The appellants could not properly look for comparison to case law dealing with only one breach, such as the breach of fiduciary duty.[19]

Even if each cause of action were viewed separately, however, the appellants' argument could not be sustained. The appellant's suggestion that the temporal limit at law for damages for breach of fiduciary duty averages between one and two years with five years being “an outlier” relied largely on cases that deal only with the fiduciary's duty not to compete with a former employer until the employer has had the chance to contact its customers and try to retain their loyalty. The driving principle was to ensure fair competition. If all that was necessary to ensure fair competition between the appellants and the respondents in the circumstances here was the opportunity to contact customers and try to retain their loyalty, those cases might have some application. However, on the facts, the unfair competition stemmed from much more than seeking to attract customers of a former employer. Of importance was the small and highly specialized market, the confidential business and technical information that the appellants misappropriated and continued to use, and the resulting product they sold as the next iteration of the respondent's suite of products. Here both the confidential business plans with their information about particular customer needs and, even more importantly, the confidential technical information at the core of the respondent's suite of computer programs, were “very special indeed”. This information allowed the appellants to market their product to the respondent's customers and potential customers as merely a seamless next step in the evolution of the respondent's programs. Confidential information of this nature provided strong support for the ten-year accounting period. Assessing the extent to which the appropriated confidential information provided the appellants with a “springboard” or a “head-start” was also important. The advantage gained from the information misappropriated by the appellants is not measured simply by the time they would have had to take to themselves develop the last iteration of the respondent's suite of programs. It must take account of the many years that went into bringing these programs from inception to where they were in the fall of 1996. That supported a longer accounting period.[20]

The court found that the reasoning of the Supreme Court of Canada in 3464920 Canada Inc. v. Strother[21] that the accounting period should last until the conflict (and therefore the damage from the fiduciary breach) was spent was of much more assistance. In this case the trial judge found a multi-faceted breach of fiduciary duty by the four personal appellants. He assessed the effects in the context of the relevant facts and found that they would not have dissipated for ten years. That was a reasonable conclusion in the circumstances that were before him.[22]

The respondent's request for permanent disgorgement of profits was also rejected on the basis that it essentially would be a monetized version of a permanent injunction. The temporal limit imposed by the trial judge recognized the reality that in the rapidly changing world of technology, information gradually loses its value and utility. At some point, it ceases to have the characteristics that require that it be cloaked in confidence. The trial judge in setting a ten-year accounting period reasonably determined that this point would likely be reached in approximately that period of time.[23]

In Zoic Studios BC Inc. v. Gannon,[24] the court, despite finding that the personal defendant and the corporate defendant misused confidential information, the Court concluded that it was not a case in which an accounting was appropriate. An accounting is usually an electable remedy where an employee has been found by the court to misuse confidential information. However, that remedy was not appropriate. The confidential information was “nothing very special.” It was only minimal pricing and financial information. The information, particularly the bid template, was something that it would not have taken anyone with experience very long to develop. The springboard effect was not for any significant length of time. The main use of the actual document was to apply for a loan from the Business Development Bank of Canada. Most of the material could have been obtained through other available means in any event. This did not allow the defendant to springboard in a dramatic fashion. To order an accounting of the profits made by the defendants from their contract with Eureka would simply be too harsh a remedy when the benefit the defendants gained from use of the confidential information was assessed. It would over-compensate the plaintiff as opposed to putting it back in the position it would have been but for the breach of confidence since the defendants did not as a result of the misuse of the confidential information obtain the Eureka contract.[25]

On appeal, the main thrust of the appellant's position was that the Trial Judge focused almost entirely on whether the employee had the legal authority to bind Zoic BC, and/or whether her authority at Zoic BC was unfettered and that the Trial Judge failed to consider whether the employee exercised discretionary power to affect Zoic BC's practical interests.[26] In dismissing the ground of appeal relating to breach of fiduciary duty, Justice Chiasson observed that the trial judge examined very thoroughly the authority of the employee, was alive to the law of fiduciary duty and that she considered the effect of the employee's authority on the interests of Zoic BC. The trial judge made no error of law. Her findings of fact were supported by the evidence.[27]

The Court of Appeal allowed the appeal to the extent only of remitting the matter to the trial judge with the direction that she consider whether an equitable accounting should be ordered arising out of the personal respondents' breach of their duty of fidelity and loyalty by competing with the appellant.[28]

In Industrial Development Consultants Ltd. v. Cooley,[29] the defendant was the managing director of the plaintiffs and, on their behalf, he entered into negotiations with the Eastern Gas Board to manage a large building project. However, the board made it clear it was not going to award the contract to the plaintiffs. Subsequently, the board approached the defendant and told him that, if he were independent of the plaintiffs, he would be chosen to do the work. The defendant procured a release from his employment contract on false grounds and eventually became the project manager for the Eastern Gas Board. The plaintiffs sued him, claiming that he was a trustee of the benefit of the contract for them. They elected to pursue an account of profits. The judge recognized that:

… if the plaintiffs succeed they will get a profit which they probably would not have got for themselves had the defendant fulfilled his duty. If the defendant is allowed to keep that profit he will have got something which he was able to get solely by reason of his breach of fiduciary duty to the plaintiffs.[30]
The court ordered the accounting on the basis that it was the defendant who had acted wrongly.[31]

The motion in Sycor Technology Inc. v. Kiaer[32] was to amend the pleadings to add the words “or through the misuse of confidential information” to the paragraph in the prayer for relief that requested an accounting. The defendants were two former employees of the plaintiffs and two businesses operated by them in apparent competition with the plaintiff. The plaintiff alleged that the defendants appropriated proprietary information, solicited customers, suppliers and employees and in so doing breached contractual, common law and fiduciary duties to the plaintiff when they went into business.[33]

The defendants objected to this amendment because they submitted it was a new cause of action and is statute barred. The Master concluded that the addition of these words to the prayer for relief, if anything limited or clarified the relief claimed in that paragraph to make it clear that the accounting was sought on the basis of the breach of confidence. The facts supporting the allegation that there was misuse of confidential information were already contained in the statement of claim and no new allegations were being added.[34]

The Master observed that Cadbury Schweppes Inc. v. FBI Foods Ltd., makes clear, an action for breach of confidence is either an action “sui generis” or is a purely equitable action. In either case the remedies must remain flexible. The Master stated that it is inaccurate to describe “breach of confidence” as an emerging nominate tort. Rather it is an action of long standing. The question was whether the addition of the impugned words to the prayer for relief was unfair to the defendants because it converted the action into an action for breach of confidence, a cause of action not previously pleaded. The words “breach of confidence” are not used in the proposed amendment. Neither the relief claimed nor the facts pleaded were altered in any way. It was quite clear that the plaintiff has always sought a number of remedies because the plaintiff accused the defendants of making use of confidential information received or originating with the plaintiff and of then misusing that information for their own benefit. It was also clear that the plaintiff sought and had always sought a variety of equitable remedies and in particular disgorgement of profits. The Master did not read the impugned words as adding a cause of action beyond a limitation period. The proposed pleading simply brought into sharper focus the basis for one of the remedies sought in the prayer for relief and why those remedies would also apply to the newly added defendant.[35]

Plaintiffs often do not receive an award of an account of profits in an expeditious manner because, after the trial, the defendant has little incentive, apart from the interest that may be awarded to the plaintiff, to provide the account expeditiously. As well, there are often disputes regarding the calculations made. Once the election is made, however, the plaintiff cannot change his or her mind.
